facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 12 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 12 of 1952. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla  Bhandari and Soni JJ.  in Criminal Appeal No. 109 of 1951 arising out of Judgment and order dated 19th March 1951 of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Ferozepore, in Sessions Trial No. 18 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th June 1951 of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla Bhandari and Soni JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla  Bhandari and Soni JJ.  in Criminal Appeal No. 109 of 1951 arising out of Judgment and order dated 19th March 1951 of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Ferozepore, in Sessions Trial No. 18 of 1951. R. Bhasin, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 109 of 1951 arising out of Judgment and order dated 19th March 1951 of the Additional Sessions Judge Ferozepore in Sessions Trial No. 18 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal No. 109 of 1951 arising out of Judgment and order dated 19th March 1951 of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Ferozepore, in Sessions Trial No. 18 of 1951. R. Bhasin, for the appellant. Gopal Singh, for the respondent. 1952. April 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.--This is a simple case though it was argued at great length on behalf of the appellant and a number of technical objections to the validity of the trial taken.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by BOSE J on April 30 1952

anchor.surface_text: 1952. April 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.--This is a simple case though it was argued at great length on behalf of the appellant and a number of technical objections to the validity of the trial taken. The appellant Bhagwan Singh has been convicted of the murder of one Buggar Singh and sentenced to death.

facts.text: Appellant Bhagwan Singh convicted of the murder of Buggar Singh and sentenced to death

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Bhagwan Singh has been convicted of the murder of one Buggar Singh and sentenced to death. He has also been convicted under section 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act but we are number concerned with that here. The prosecution story is that the appellant bore a grudge against the deceased because the deceased had fired at the appellants brother some six or seven years before the present occurrence and was sent to jail for it.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under section 19 of the Indian Arms Act

anchor.surface_text: He has also been convicted under section 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act but we are number concerned with that here. The prosecution story is that the appellant bore a grudge against the deceased because the deceased had fired at the appellants brother some six or seven years before the present occurrence and was sent to jail for it.

facts.text: Deceased had fired at appellant's brother six or seven years before the occurrence and was sent to jail for it

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution story is that the appellant bore a grudge against the deceased because the deceased had fired at the appellants brother some six or seven years before the present occurrence and was sent to jail for it. When he came out of jail the police thought it prudent to take proceedings against both sides under section 107 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Proceedings under section 107 CrPC resulted in appellant's two brothers and cousins being bound down as also the deceased

anchor.surface_text: When he came out of jail the police thought it prudent to take proceedings against both sides under section 107 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This resulted in the appellants two brothers and his cousins being bound down, as also the deceased. This, it is said, constituted the motive for the present crime.

facts.text: Occurrence on 7th September 1950

anchor.surface_text: On the date of the occurrence, the 7th of September 1950, the prosecution state that the appellant was sitting at the shop of Jit Singh, P.W. 2, when the deceased came there about 12-15 p.m. and borrowed Rs. 5 from Jit Singh who lent him the money and entered the transaction in his account book.

facts.text: Appellant sitting at shop of Jit Singh PW2 when deceased came about 12:15 pm and borrowed Rs.5 from Jit Singh who entered it in account book

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution state that the appellant was sitting at the shop of Jit Singh, P.W. 2, when the deceased came there about 12-15 p.m. and borrowed Rs. 5 from Jit Singh who lent him the money and entered the transaction in his ac- count book. When the deceased left the shop he was followed by the appellant who shot him at point blank range with a pistol only 4 or 5 karams from the shop.

facts.text: Appellant followed deceased and shot him at point blank range with pistol 4 or 5 karams from the shop

anchor.surface_text: When the deceased left the shop he was followed by the appellant who shot him at point blank range with a pistol only 4 or 5 karams from the shop. This attracted the attention of a number of bystanders who immediately chased the appellant and apprehended him after a short run of about 30 karams.

facts.text: Bystanders chased appellant and apprehended him after short run of 30 karams, still carrying pistol taken by Jagir Singh Patwari PW4

anchor.surface_text: This attracted the attention of a number of bystanders who immediately chased the appellant and apprehended him after a short run of about 30 karams. He was still carrying the pistol. It was taken away from him by Jagir Singh Patwari, P.W. 4.

facts.text: Appellant taken to local police post 100 karams distant, Jit Singh PW2 made first information report at 12:27 pm within 15 minutes

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was immediately taken to the local police post about 100 karams distant and the shopkeeper Jit Singh, W. 2, made the first information report at 12-a7 p.m. within 15 minutes of the occurrence. The motive is proved by Bhag Singh, P.W. 7, who has been believed and that part of the case was number challenged before us.

facts.text: Motive proved by Bhag Singh PW7 who has been believed

anchor.surface_text: The motive is proved by Bhag Singh, P.W. 7, who has been believed and that part of the case was number challenged before us. The occurrence was witnessed by a large number of persons of whom the prosecution examined only five.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by large number of persons, prosecution examined five, two turned hostile, one neutral, Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6 believed

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence was witnessed by a large number of persons of whom the prosecution examined only five. Two of them turned hostile in the Sessions Court and one gave evidence which has been regarded by the High Court as neu- tral. The remaining two, Balbir Singh  P.W. 5  and Jaswant Singh  P.W. 6  have been believed.

facts.text: Jaswant Singh PW6 not examined by Committing Magistrate because he had gone away and was not available

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued that the evidence of Jaswant Singh P.W. 6, is viti- ated because he was number examined by the Committing Magis- trate. It was said that makes his evidence in the Sessions Court inadmissible. This raises a question which is largely academic in this case because the reason Jaswant Singh, P.W. 6, was number examined by the Committing Magistrate is that the witness had gone away and was number available

facts.text: Appellant apprehended on the spot within a minute or two of the murder with pistol still in possession

anchor.surface_text: Now the High Court bases its decision on the evidence of these eye-witnesses and on the fact that the appellant was apprehended on the spot within a minute or two of the murder with the pistol still in his possession, and had the learned Judges stopped there, there would have been numberfoundation for the very elaborate network of technicalities

facts.text: First information report recorded within 15 minutes of occurrence

anchor.surface_text: and had the learned Judges stopped there, there would have been numberfoundation for the very elaborate network of technicalities upon which the learned companynsel for the appellant embarked. But Bhand- ari J.  Soni J. companycurring  after saying that After a careful companysideration of all the facts and circumstances of the case I entertain numberdoubt in my mind that Balbir Singh and Jaswant Singh P. Ws. have told numberhing but the truth

facts.text: Jit Singh PW2 supported prosecution in examination-in-chief but resiled in cross-examination, treated as hostile

anchor.surface_text: We will deal with Jit Singh, P.W. 2, first. He supported the prosecution case in his examination-inchief but resiled when cross-examined. He was therefore treated as hostile and the learned Public Prosecutor was permitted to cross-examine him.

facts.text: Jagir Singh PW4 hostile from the start

anchor.surface_text: We turn next to Jagir Singh, P.W. 4. In his case there was numberchoice. He was hostile from the start and in his ease our observations in the ruling just referred to apply in full.

facts.text: Appellant represented by two counsel in Sessions Court

anchor.surface_text: The proper time to object to such a procedure would be at the trial itself, and as the appellant was represented in the Sessions Court by two companynsel it is too late to object to such a venial irregularity in this Court.

facts.text: Jaswant Singh mentioned as eye-witness in first information report and in calendar of committal proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We do number think so because Jaswant Singh was mentioned in the first information report, recorded within 15 minutes of the occurrence, as one of the eye-witnesses and he was again mentioned as an eye-witness in the calendar of the companymittal proceedings.

facts.text: Man caught red-handed with pistol still in hand, first information report recorded practically on the spot within 15 minutes

anchor.surface_text: As we said at the outset, the case is a very simple one in which a man was caught red-handed with a pistol still in his hand and in which the first information report was recorded practically on the spot within 15 minutes of the occurrence.

holdings.text: The Sessions Court has power under section 540 CrPC to examine witnesses not examined before the Committing Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: It is evident that the Sessions Court has power to examine wit- nesses who were number examined before the Committing Magis- trate because of section 540 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and if the witness is treated as a prosecution witness and examined by the prosecuting companynsel instead of by the Court itself that at best would be an irregularity curable by section 537.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of S.540 CrPC; if examined by prosecutor, irregularity curable by S.537; no objection raised at trial.

holdings.text: Irregularity of examining witness as prosecution witness instead of court witness under S.540 is curable by S.537 CrPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power under S.540; curable if no prejudice; objection too late as appellant represented by two counsel.

holdings.text: Section 540 CrPC provides complete answer to objections under Chapter XVIII including S.208(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.540 overrides; precedents like Sher Bahadur concede power; decision on prejudice absent here.

holdings.text: No prejudice to appellant from examining Jaswant Singh as he was named in FIR and committal calendar.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think so because Jaswant Singh was mentioned in the first information report, recorded within 15 minutes of the occurrence, as one of the eye-witnesses and he was again mentioned as an eye-witness in the calendar of the companymittal proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior notice in FIR and committal; right to police statement under S.162 not exercised; full prosecution case known.

holdings.text: Previous consistent statements can corroborate chief evidence under S.157 Evidence Act even if oral; S.145 not applicable if statement admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the former statement companyld number be used as substantive evidence. It would only be used as companyroboration of the evidence in chief under section 157 of the Evidence Act or to shake the witnesss credit or test his veracity under section 146, Section 145 is number called into play at all in such a case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.157 for corroboration; S.145 only if denial; prosecution choice to corroborate chief not contradict cross.

holdings.text: S.288 CrPC makes previous deposition substantive evidence subject to all Evidence Act provisions including S.157 for corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: but even without section 288 a Court would be entitled to say in such a case, basing on the evidence in chief, which is substantive evidence. that what the witness said to the police, or to the Committing Magistrate, is the true version, number because those statements form substantive evidence but. because they tally with the evidence in chief which is substantive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.288 'subject to Evidence Act' includes S.157; even without S.288, corroborates chief; distinguishes Tara Singh.

holdings.text: Substantial compliance with S.145 Evidence Act for Jagir Singh as attention drawn point by point and whole statement admitted.

anchor.surface_text: but it was argued that this was done without drawing the witnesss attention to the parts of the writing which were to be used for the purposes of companytradiction. We are by numbermeans satisfied that is the ease because at least one of the passages is reproduced in inverted companymas and so must have been read out from the statement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point by point questioning then whole short statement read and admitted; fair opportunity; substance over form.

holdings.text: Presumption under S.80 Evidence Act that deposition read over and correct; burden on challenger to disprove; no duty to enquire.

anchor.surface_text: The Court is bound to accept this as companyrect under section 80 of the Indian Evidence Act until it is proved to be untrue. The burden is on the person seeking to displace the statutory presumption and if he chooses to rely on the testimony of a witness which the Court is number prepared to believe the matter ends there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory presumption; court not bound to believe witness or examine magistrate; cites Nazir Ahmad.

holdings.text: Failure to read over deposition is curable irregularity under S.360 CrPC unless prejudice shown by affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the reading over prescribed by section 360 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is number to enable the witness to change his story but to ensure that the record faithfully and accurately embodies the gist of what the witness actually said.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose to ensure accuracy not change story; prejudice must specify inaccuracies via affidavit; cites Abdul Rahman.

holdings.text: No duty on court for roving enquiry into collateral allegations like police duress in statements.

anchor.surface_text: Here again, it is numberpart of a Courts duty to enter upon a roving enquiry in the middle of a trial on matters which are companylateral to the main issue. The burden is on the person making these allegations to substantiate them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on maker; unsubstantiated evidence fails; no roving enquiry.

holdings.text: Substantial compliance with S.342 CrPC as crucial facts put to accused; no prejudice shown.

anchor.surface_text: It was also argued that there was numberproper companypliance with the provisions. of section 342 of the Criminal Proce- dure Code. We are satisfied that there was substantial companypliance in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Simple facts; crucial matters raised; no specific prejudice or answers disclosed even in argument.

holdings.text: Conviction can be rested on testimony of Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining two, Balbir Singh  P.W. 5  and Jaswant Singh  P.W. 6  have been believed. The only questions are  1  whether the companyviction can be rested on their testimony and 2  whether certain irregularities in the trial vitiate it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Believed by High Court; corroborated by immediate apprehension with pistol, prompt FIR, motive; simple straightforward case.

holdings.text: Technical irregularities do not vitiate the trial.

anchor.surface_text: their testimony and 2  whether certain irregularities in the trial vitiate it. No attack was made on the testimony of Balbir Singh, W. 5, except that the two eye-witnesses who resiled in the Sessions Court companytradict him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice in any irregularity; strong circumstantial evidence; all objections rejected on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Tara Singh v. The State 1  is to be distinguished because there, there were numbertwo versions in the companyrse of the same testimony. anchor.surface_text: marks we made in Kashmera Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1  based on the decision of the Privy Council in Nazir Ahmad v.
